entry.et: Middle English, from Old English būgan; akin to Old High German biogan to bend, Sanskrit bhujati he bends

def.dt: :to cease from competition or resistance :submit yield refusing to bow to the inevitable John O'Hara
:to suffer defeat bowed to the champion
:to bend the head, body, or knee in reverence, submission, or shame
:to incline the head or body in salutation or assent or to acknowledge applause
:debut the play will bow next month
:to cause to incline
:to incline (as the head) especially in respect or submission
:to crush with a heavy burden
:to express by bowing
:to usher in or out with a bow
:a bending of the head or body in respect, submission, assent, or salutation
:a show of respect or submission

entry.et: Middle English bowe, from Old English boga; akin to Old English būgan

def.dt: :something bent into a simple curve
:rainbow
:a weapon that is made of a strip of flexible material (as wood) with a cord connecting the two ends and holding the strip bent and that is used to propel an arrow
:archer
:a metal ring or loop forming a handle (as of a key)
:a knot formed by doubling a ribbon or string into two or more loops
:bow tie 1
:a frame for the lenses of eyeglasses
:the sidepiece of the frame passing over the ear
:a wooden rod with horsehairs stretched from end to end used in playing an instrument of the viol or violin family
:a stroke of such a bow
:to bend into a curve
:to play a stringed musical instrument with a bow
:to cause to bend into a curve
:to play (a stringed instrument) with a bow

entry.et: Middle English bowe, bowgh, probably from Middle Dutch boech bow, shoulder; akin to Old English bōg bough

def.dt: :the forward part of a ship often used in plural crossing the bows
:bowman
river 315 miles (507 kilometers) Canada in SW Alberta rising in Banff National Park
:the bells of the Church of St. Mary-le-Bow in London
:retire withdraw
:lose bowed out in the first round of the tournament
:a saw having a narrow blade held under tension by a light bow-shaped frame
:the shock wave formed by the collision of a stellar wind with another medium (as the magnetosphere of a planet)
